name: Stevan Harnad : What AI Is & Isn't, and Can & Can't Do
location: Building 21 - 651 Sherbrooke St. W, Montreal, QC
description: Join Encode Justice Canada‚Äôs first Speaker Series event of the year featuring Professor Stevan Harnad, a Hungarian cognitive scientist whose research focuses on cognition, categorization, communication, and consciousness. He often discusses important topics such as categorical perception, the Turing Test, the symbol grounding problem and language acquisition. He was the founder of the scientific journal Behavioural and Brain Sciences, as well as the open-access journals Pscycoloquy, CogPrints, American Scientist Open Access Forum. He is passionate about animal rights and veganism, and is the Editor-in-Chief of the refereed journal Animal Sentience. Harnad is currently a professor at UQAM and teaches PSYC 538 (Categorization, Communication and Consciousness) at McGill.üß†

name: AI in Healthcare
description: Our Events Team presents two contrasting views and provide curated articles for lively chats. Don‚Äôt forget your laptop for easy access to articles and note-taking, along with your mug for tea, cookies, and engaging conversations!

name: MUTEK Forum 2024
location: Monument-National and the Society for Arts and Technology
description: EJC is excited to announce that we are presenting a panel at the 10th edition of the MUTEK Forum! This international gathering and marketplace of ideas for digital culture, art, technology, and society is taking place from August 20th to August 23rd at the Monument-National and the Soci√©t√© des arts technologiques [SAT] EJC's Cleo Norris will be moderating the panel 'Shaping Spaces: Community, Sustainability, AI, and Justice,'. We are honoured to provide a Gen Z perspective on human-centered technological futures alongside 90 international speakers and experts in AI, XR, sustainability, music, architecture and video games.

name: Alexis Morin-Martel : Machine Learning in Court Decisions
location: Building 21 - 651 Sherbrooke St. W, Montreal, QC
description: Exploring the frontier where law meets technology! Encode Justice Canada proudly presents Alexis Morin-Martel, a PhD candidate from McGill, as part of our Speaker Series. Alexis unravels the intricate relationship between machine learning algorithms and court decisions. Delve deep into his research on AI‚Äôs role in bail decisions and its impact on judges‚Äô trustworthiness. Stay for snacks and a stimulating conversation!

name: AI & Robotics Workshop
description: The Montreal Youth core team of Women in AI & Robotics, in collaboration with McGill Robotics, McWiCS - McGill Women in Computer Science, Women in Tech - WIT and Encode Justice Canada is bringing you an AI & Robotics Workshop where you'll gain valuable hands-on skills and knowledge on computervision, reinforcementlearning, and ROS programming language.

name: Chit-Chat - AI and Humans: The Imitation Game
location: Building 21 - 651 Sherbrooke St. W, Montreal, QC
description: Come chat about the opportunities and challenges of AI as we explore AI and Humans: The Imitation Game. See you there!

name: Skyler Wang: On-Demand Intimacy and the Future of Human-AI Intimacy
location: Building 21 - 651 Sherbrooke St. W, Montreal, QC
description: Encode Canada is excited to welcome Skyler Wang as the first speaker of the 2025 speaker series. Skyler Wang is an Assistant Professor at McGill University and is currently teaching both SOCI235 Technology & Society and SOCI345 Social and Intimate Relationships in the Digital Age. Trained sociologist, he used to work at the Foundational AI Research (FAIR) lab at Meta. Some of his research areas of interest include social-centered AI, technology, foundational machine translation, and human-AI interactions.  His work transcends disciplinary boundaries and has been featured in journals and platforms such as Nature, Big Data & Society, TIME, CNN and WIRED. His most recent projects explore how relationships and intimacy are shaped by digital platforms in this day and age. It also examines human-AI interactions; with the emergence of artificial companions, our norms around intimacy are bound to change, and so will on-demand intimacy. Enjoy a short presentation and bring your questions for an interactive panel-style discussion to dive deeper into the topics of intimacy in the context of the rise of AI on our everyday life. What can AI teach us about our view of intimate relationships? Are AI companions mirroring human-human relationship? What are the benefits of starting a human-AI relationship?

name: AI Lightning Brainstorm
location: Building 21 - 651 Sherbrooke St. W, Montreal, QC
description: Join us for another AI Hub where we give students a chance to explore some of their own thoughts, projects, and ideas related to responsible AI. This event will feature an open table discussion where people can brainstorm together. Whether you want to learn from others, receive insights on an ongoing project, or approach an AI related problem from a new perspective, this event is for you! You might also be inspired to present at Encode Canada‚Äôs Student Presentations happening later in March (more to come soon!). Come chat with us and get creative!
